definition: All of space and time and everything that exists within them—stars, planets, energy, and matter.
examples: Astronomers study how the Universe began.
Our galaxy is only a tiny part of the Universe.

extra.memory_tip: Universe = one (uni) whole verse of everything.

definition: Another choice or option; describing something different from the usual.
examples: We need an alternative if it rains. (noun)
There are alternative routes to school. (adjective)

extra.memory_tip: Alternative = an ‘other native’ path to take.

definition: People who study and write about the past using evidence.
examples: Historians analyse diaries and maps to learn about events.
Modern historians often compare many sources.

definition: A way of understanding art, literature, or maths by focusing on form, structure, and rules rather than content or context.
examples: In poetry, formalism values rhyme and metre.
Some maths proofs rely on strict formalism.

definition: A journey with a clear purpose, often for exploration, research, or war.
examples: The team prepared for an Arctic expedition.
A science expedition collected rock samples.

extra.memory_tip: Expedition = a planned ‘expedient’ trip with goals.

definition: The force that pulls objects toward each other; seriousness of a situation.
examples: Gravity keeps our feet on the ground.
She spoke with gravity about the crisis.

definition: The four-dimensional fabric that combines space and time, used to describe the Universe in physics.
examples: Mass bends space-time around planets.
GPS works by accounting for space-time effects.

extra.memory_tip: Space-time = space and time woven together.

definition: Fixed firmly inside something; placed deeply within.
examples: Fossils embedded in rock tell ancient stories.
The reporter was embedded with the unit.

extra.memory_tip: Embedded = ‘in-bedded’ like set in a bed of material.

definition: Causing a great change; a person who supports or takes part in a revolution.
examples: It was a revolutionary idea in medicine. (adjective)
The revolutionary planned reforms. (noun)

definition: When one celestial body blocks the light of another; to overshadow or outshine.
examples: We watched a solar eclipse with special glasses. (noun)
Her performance eclipsed all others. (verb)

definition: The amount by which something bends or curves.
examples: The curvature of Earth is slight to the eye.
Designers measured the curvature of the lens.

extra.memory_tip: Curvature = how ‘curvy’ a line or surface is.

definition: Admired and trusted by many people.
examples: She is a respected scientist in her field.
It’s a respected tradition in the community.

definition: Making you very tired; draining energy completely.
examples: Climbing the ridge was exhausting.
It was an exhausting day of exams.

extra.memory_tip: Exhausting = like an engine’s exhaust—energy all used up.

definition: A system of methods used in a particular area of study or activity.
examples: Their research methodology was clearly explained.
Good methodology helps others repeat an experiment.

extra.memory_tip: Methodology = the logic behind your methods.

definition: Very important; expressing careful judgment; at a dangerous or intense point.
examples: Water safety is critical in chemistry labs.
She wrote a critical review of the book.

extra.memory_tip: Critical = at the ‘crisis’ point or judging carefully.

definition: Showing signs of future success or good results.
examples: The data show promising results.
She is a promising young engineer.

extra.memory_tip: Promising = like a promise of success ahead.
